review.title: Near-Optimal Joint Object Matching via Convex Relaxation
review.abstract: Joint matching over a collection of objects aims at aggregating information from a large collection of similar instances (e.g. images, graphs, shapes) to improve maps between pairs of them. Given multiple matches computed between a few object pairs in isolation, the goal is to recover an entire collection of maps that are (1) globally consistent, and (2) close to the provided maps --- and under certain conditions provably the ground-truth maps. Despite recent advances on this problem, the best-known recovery guarantees are limited to a small constant barrier --- none of the existing methods find theoretical support when more than $50\%$ of input correspondences are corrupted. Moreover, prior approaches focus mostly on fully similar objects, while it is practically more demanding to match instances that are only partially similar to each other.
review.SUBJECTS: cs.LG cs.CV cs.IT math.IT math.OC stat.ML

metadata.title: Near-Optimal Joint Object Matching via Convex Relaxation

sections.text: In this paper, we propose an algorithm to merge several objects with only partial similarities, since there are few (possibly highly incomplete) pairs of matches that are highly corrupted. By encoding a consistent partial map collection into a semi-definitive matrix 0-1, we propose to restore the ground-truth maps using a parameter-free convex program called MatchLift, which follows a spectral method that predicts the total number of elements to be compared. Numerically, this program can be efficiently solved by alternating direction multipliers (ADMM) methods together with a greedy rounding strategy. Theoretically, MatchLift exhibits near-optimal error correction capability, i.e. in the asymptotic regime, it is guaranteed to work even if a dominant fraction of 1 − в (log2n) of the input cards is lively.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: 1.1 Contributions
sections.text: Our main contributions in this regard are threefold: 1. Algorithms: Inspired by recent evidence of the power of convex relaxation, we propose solving the common matching problem using a semi-definitive program called MatchLift. The algorithm loosens the binary value constraints and tries to maximize compatibility between the input and the recovered cards. It is based on a semi-defined conical constraint based on the total number of elements to be assigned. To this end, we propose to anticipate compatibility using a spectral method. Our methodology is essentially parameter-free and can be solved by scalable optimization algorithms. 2. Theory: We derive performance guarantees for exact matches.

sections.heading: 1.2 Prior Art
sections.text: There are a number of reasons why we have to behave in such a way that we are not able to find a solution, "he said in an interview with the German Press Agency." sections.heading: 1.3 Organization
sections.text: The rest of the paper is broken down as follows: Section 2 formally sets out the problem, including the input model and expected output. Our two-step recovery method - a spectral method followed by a convex program called MatchLift - is described in Section 3. A scalable method of inversion multipliers (ADMM) together with a greedy rounding strategy is also presented in Section 3. Section 4 presents the main theoretical performance guarantees for our method according to a natural randomized model. All the evidence of the main theories are moved to the appendices. We present numerical experiments demonstrating the practicality of our method in Section 5, as well as an empirical comparison with other well-known algorithms. Finally, Section 6 concludes the paper with a summary of our results.

sections.heading: 2 Problem Formulation and Preliminaries
sections.text: This section presents the problem of the correspondence of several partially similar objects and introduces an algebraic form to represent a collection of pairs of maps.

sections.heading: 2.1 Terminology
sections.text: In the following, we will formally define several important terms used in this essay. • Set. We will present objects that should match as discrete groups. For example, these groups can represent the vertices of the graph matching problem or encode characteristic points if images match. • Partial map. In the case of two discrete groups S and S, not all elements need to be paired. • Map chart. A chart G = (V, E) is called a partial chart if each element of S (or S) is paired with at most one element of S (or S) - in particular, not all elements need to be paired. • Map chart. A chart G = (V, E) is called a map chart w.r.t. n sets S1, · · ·, Sn if (i) V: = {S1, ·, Sn} and (ii) (Si, Sj) e implies that pairwise estimates are available on the partial maps between Si and Sj.

sections.heading: 2.2 Input and Output
sections.text: The input and expected output for the common object matching problem are described as follows: • Input (Noisy Pairwise Maps). Given n sets S1, · · ·, Sn with corresponding cardinality m1, · · ·, mn and a (possibly sparse) chart chart G, the input for the recovery algorithm consists of partial maps φinij ((((((i, j) ΔG)) between Si and Sj, which are estimated in isolation using any common pair matching method. Note that the input maps obtained may partially or completely disagree with the soil truth. • Output (Consistent Global Matching). The main objective of this paper is to detect and truncate false pairs of maps entered in an efficient and reliable manner. Specifically, we aim to propose a traceable algorithm that returns a complete collection of partial maps.

sections.heading: 2.3 Joint Matching in Matrix Form
sections.text: In the same sense as most convex relaxation techniques (e.g. [12, 30]), we use matrices to encode maps between objects. Specifically, we encode a submap φij: Si 7 → Sj as binary matrix Xij. Xij must meet the following double substochastic constraints: 0 ≤ Xij1 ≤ 1, 0 ≤ X > ij1 ≤ 1. (1) We then use a n · n block matrix X х {0, 1} N · N to encode the entire collection of partial maps.

sections.heading: 3 Methodology
sections.text: This section presents a novel methodology based on a theoretically rigorous and numerically efficient framework.

sections.heading: 3.1 MatchLift: A Novel Two-Step Algorithm
sections.text: We begin by discussing the consistency restriction to the underlying basic truth maps. > Assuming that there is a universe S = {1, · m} of m elements, so that each object Si is a (partial) image of S; ii) every element in S is contained in at least one object Si. > Then the ground truth correspondences will connect points associated with the same element. & # 8222; s & # 8220; s & # 8220; s & # 8222; s & # 8222; s & # 8222; s & # 8222; s & # 8222; s & # 8222; s & # 8222; s & # 8222; s & # 8222; s & # 8222.

sections.heading: 3.2 Alternating Direction Methods of Multipliers (ADMM)
sections.text: For practical use, we propose a first-order optimization algorithm to approximate MatchLift solution, which is a variant of the ADMM method for semi-defined programs presented in [37]. Theoretically, convergence is guaranteed. Empirically, it is often the case that ADMM converges within a reasonable period of time to modest accuracy and produces desired results with the help of appropriate rounding procedures. In our case, this property makes ADMM practically attractive, since the ground-truth matrix is known as a 0-1 matrix, for which moderate input precision is sufficient to ensure good rounding accuracy. Details of the ADMM algorithm are moved to Appendix A.

sections.heading: 3.3 Rounding Strategy
sections.text: Since MatchLift solves a relaxed program of the original convex problem, it can return fractional solutions. In this case, we propose a greedy rounding method to generate valid partial cards. In view of solution X for MatchLift, the proposed strategy proceeds as in Algorithm 2. It can be verified that this simple deterministic rounding strategy delivers a matrix that encodes a consistent collection of partial cards. Note that vTi denotes the ith line of a matrix V, where r is an estimate of the total number of points to be recovered. Form V = Up 1 2. Repeat 1) Let O be a uniform matrix that obeys Ov1 = e1, and sentence V ← V > 2. For each of the remaining rows, distinctive features that need to be restored are specified. Form V = Up 1 2. Repeat 1) Let O be a uniform matrix that obeys Ov1 = e1, and sentence V > 2 are removed for each remaining Sv = 1.

sections.heading: 4 Theoretical Guarantees: Exact Recovery
sections.text: Our heuristic algorithm MatchLift restores the ground truth maps under a natural random environment, even if only a vanishing part of the input correspondence is correct. Furthermore, MatchLift is successful with minimal input complexity, i.e. the algorithm is guaranteed to work as soon as the input cards that match the ground truth maps form a coherent map graph.

sections.heading: 4.1 Randomized Model
sections.text: In the following, we present a natural randomized model according to which the feature of MatchLift is easiest to interpret. Specifically, we consider a universe [m]: = {1, 2, · ·, m}. The random setting that is taken into account here is generated by the following method. • For each quantity of Si (1 ≤ i ≤ n), each point s [m] is independently recorded with probability set in Si. • Each X inij is independently observed / calculated with probability points. • Each observed X inij independently agrees with the basic probability ptrue = 1 − pfalse. • Each observed but incorrect X inij is independently satisfied from a series of submap matrices EX inij = 1m 1 · 1 > when X inij is observed and corrected. sections.heading: 4.3 Comparison with Prior Approaches
sections.text: Our exact recovery state significantly exceeds the most known performance guarantees, including various SDP heuristics for matching problems and general graph clustering approaches, when applied to object comparisons described below. • Semidefinitive programming: The SDP formulation proposed by Wang and Singer [17] allows for an exact recovery in full similarity setting when ptrue > c1 for an absolute constant c1 ≈ 50% in the asymptotic regime. One could also try to induce recovery by minimizing a weighted sum of core norm and "1 norm," as proposed in the matrix completion [19], and robust PCA [21.22]. To allow for a dense error correction, robust PCA − the sparse components (which X in − Xgt here specifies the basic truth) require random characters [24 characters] that cannot be distorted outside of our Xmuster − all of the negative Xmuster support.

sections.heading: 5 Experimental Evaluation
sections.text: In this section, we evaluate the performance of MatchLift and compare it with [29] and other graph matching methods. We look at both synthetic examples used to verify the exact recovery conditions described above, as well as popular benchmark data sets to assess practicality on real-world images.

sections.heading: 5.1 Synthetic Examples
sections.text: In all examples, we set the universe size to consist of m = 16 points, and then vary the remaining parameters, i.e. n, pset, and pfalse, to assess the performance of an algorithm. We evaluate 31 x 36 sets of parameters for each scenario in which each parameter configuration is simulated by 10 Monte Carlo experiments. Empirical probability of success is reflected in the color of each cell. Blue represents perfect recovery in all experiments, and red represents failure in all processes. Figure 1 (a) illustrates the phase transition for pset = 0.6 when the number of objects n and pfalse is different. We can see that MatchLift is accurate even if the majority of the input correspondence is wrong (e.g. 75% grabs = 150), which is consistent with the result of the second phase (Matchv1).

sections.heading: 5.2 Real-World Examples
sections.text: We applied our algorithm to six benchmark datasets, i.e. CMU House, CMU Hotel, two datasets (Graf and Bikes) from [39] 1, and two new datasets (Chair and Building), which were developed for the evaluation of a shared sub-object matching. As shown in Figures 2 and 3, the building dataset contains 16 images taken around a building [4], while the chair dataset contains 16 images of a chair model from different angles. In the following, we will discuss the procedure for generating the input into our algorithm, i.e. the input sets and the output maps. We will then present the evaluation structure and analyze the results. • Characteristics and output maps. To make fair comparisons with previous techniques on CMUHouse and CMU Hotel, we will use the characteristic points provided in [15], and apply the spectral matching1100 online collection available to 9.9% -99.99.999% / object -99.99.9% -99.9% -99.99.9%% -99.99.9% -99.99.9%%%% -99.99.99.9% -%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: This paper provides some encouraging news: in the face of some isolated calculations of noisy object matches, a collection of partially similar objects can be accurately mapped using semi-defined relaxation - an approach that has been shown to work under dense error. Essentially, the proposed algorithm is parameter-free and can be solved by achieving remarkable efficiency and accuracy through a greedy rounding strategy; the proposed algorithm achieves near-optimal error correction capability because it is guaranteed to work even if much of the input is corrupted, underscoring the importance of common object matching: no matter how poor the quality of the input sources may be, perfect matching is achievable as long as we obtain enough instances. Although partial matching can cause much more serious input errors than full matching, the restoration capability of our algorithm in many situations is almost the same as restoring full similarity (to some factor).

sections.heading: A Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM)

We can see that MatchLift can recover the ground-truth maps even the majority of the input correspondences are wrong, while the exact recovery of [29] requires that the percentage of incorrect correspondences is less than 50%.
In comparison, Figure 1(b) and Figure 1(d) illustrate the phase transition diagrams achieved by the algorithm proposed in [29].
One can see that MatchLift is empirically superior, as [29] is unable to allow dense error correction in our case.

metadata.abstractText: Joint matching over a collection of objects aims at aggregating information from a large collection of similar instances (e.g. images, graphs, shapes) to improve maps between pairs of them. Given multiple objects and matches computed between a few object pairs in isolation, the goal is to recover an entire collection of maps that are (1) globally consistent, and (2) close to the provided maps — and under certain conditions provably the ground-truth maps. Despite recent advances on this problem, the best-known recovery guarantees are limited to a small constant barrier — none of the existing methods find theoretical support when more than 50% of input correspondences are corrupted. Moreover, prior approaches focus mostly on fully similar objects, while it is practically more demanding to match instances that are only partially similar to each other (e.g., different views of a single physical object). In this paper, we propose an algorithm to jointly match multiple objects that exhibit only partial similarities, given a few (possibly highly incomplete) pairwise matches that are densely corrupted. By encoding a consistent partial map collection into a 0-1 semidefinite matrix, we propose to recover the ground-truth maps via a parameter-free convex program called MatchLift, following a spectral method that pre-estimates the total number of distinct elements to be matched. Numerically, this program can be efficiently solved via alternating direction methods of multipliers (ADMM) along with a greedy rounding strategy. Theoretically, MatchLift exhibits near-optimal error-correction ability, i.e. in the asymptotic regime it is guaranteed to work even when a dominant fraction 1 − Θ ( log n √ n ) of the input maps behave like random outliers. Furthermore, MatchLift succeeds with minimal input complexity, namely, perfect matching can be achieved as soon as the provided maps form a connected map graph. We evaluate the proposed algorithm on various benchmark data sets including synthetic examples and real-world examples, all of which confirm the practical applicability and usefulness of MatchLift.
